channel.title: Japan: 1868-1968
channel.description:
A lecture series on the centennial of the beginning of the modernization of Japan, featuring John M. Maki, University of Massachusetts.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Episode 5: Japan and Emperor Hirohito
item.description: In this program, Professor Maki profiles Emperor Hirohito, who took power--after acting as his ill father's regent--at a time when Japan was both newly accepted as a world power and suffering from a recession as a result of uneven economic development.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World War, 1939-1945

item.title: Episode 11: Japan: The New Democracy
item.description: Although democratic ideas go back to the late 1800s in Japan, little if anything in that country's history and culture could have provided a foundation for the development of a Japanese form of democracy. In this program, Professor Maki describes how, during the postwar occupation, the Japanese people came to embrace democracy's rights, freedoms, ideas, and practices.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 4: The Reign of the Emperor Taisho
item.description: Japanese Emperor Taisho was born on August 1, 1879, ascended to the throne on July 30, 1912, and was dethroned because of mental derangement on November 10, 1915. According to Professor Maki, the Taisho period is characterized by the continued development of modernization as well as Japan's entry into World War I.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World War, 1914-1918

item.title: Episode 2: The Mid-19th Century Crisis
item.description: From roughly 1850--and more precisely 1868, the first year of Japan's modern Centennial--Japan was confronted with two crises: the internal crisis created by broad but almost invisible change inside Japan; secondly, the external crisis usually referred to as the coming of the West. In this program, Professor Maki describes how the combination of both crises set the stage for the process of modernization.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 10: The Occupation of Japan
item.description: In this program, Professor Maki describes the pivotal seven years of mostly American occupation after the war, including the interaction and intermingling of the two societies as well as Japan's progress in rebuilding a destroyed economy and moving toward a democratic government.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 1: Japan and Modernization
item.description: The year 1868 marked one of the most momentous events in all of Japan's long history: the coronation of Emperor Meiji. What happened afterward is referred to sometimes as the imperial restoration, sometimes the Meiji restoration. In 1968, Japan is celebrating the centennial of that event, popularly viewed as marking the end of the first century of Japan's process of modernization. In this introductory program, Professor Maki begins his analysis of a number of issues and events that have carried Japan's history over the past century.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 12: Japan: The New Society
item.description: Professor Maki discusses some of the changes in Japanese society since 1945, which he describes as a transition from a modern authoritarian to a modern democratic society, including constitutional freedoms such as human rights and universal suffrage; maintaining a policy of pacifism in the face of encroaching communism; the rise of agricultural development and land ownership; and the economic miracle of Japanese production and consumer affluence as a consequence of postwar reconstruction.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Episode 8: Prelude to Pearl Harbor
item.description: In the 10 years from September 18th, 1931--the beginning of the Manchurian Incident--to the attack on Pearl Harbor, there had been an accelerating sharpness of the confrontation between the United States and Japan. But perhaps even more significantly, this growing enmity and dislike between the two governments was being worked out in a broad international scene. Professor Maki looks at the development of the American-Japanese rivalry, which began during the 19th century, primarily over the interests of the two governments in China.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 9: Japan and the A-Bomb
item.description: The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on December 7th, 1941, was both a tactical achievement of great brilliance and a strategic blunder of the first magnitude, since it created an enemy with a military potential that Japan simply could not hope to match. By June, 1945, both Japan and the United States were confronted with fundamental questions: the American problem was how to end the war without an invasion of Japan; and the Japanese problem was how to end the war on what the Japanese would regard as reasonable terms. This program looked at the events leading to the destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki by nuclear weapons as well as Japan's surrender.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World War, 1939-1945

item.title: Episode 3: The Reign of the Emperor Meiji
item.description: This program profiles Emperor Meiji (1852-1912), the first of Japan's modern emperors, whose coronation marked the true beginning of the intensely complicated problem of modernization inside Japan.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 6: The Roots of Militarism
item.description: The decade of the 1930s was marked by the beginning of a major phase of Japan's aggression. Professor Maki traces Japanese aggression and its military tradition to the warrior class, which became the dominant class in Japanese society in about the middle of the 12th century A.D.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World War, 1939-1945

item.title: Episode 7: The Roots of Aggression
item.description: Professor Maki describes the causes and impact of the Manchurian Incident of 1931--during which the Japanese army began a military attack and occupation of the northeastern provinces of China--a reaction in part to economic, political, and diplomatic developments under Japan's civilian government.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 13: Japan: A Century of Change
item.description: In his final lecture, Professor Maki reviews recent social changes in Japan, including improving conditions for women, a relaxation of the previously authoritarian family structure, consumerism, the changing work ethic, and the impact of urbanization.
item.dc:creator: Four College Radio
item.dc:subject: Women
